senses.de: Applying to all or most parts, members, or aspects of something
senses.ex: She expressed her general approval of the plan

Tips.title: Broad Application
Tips.description: Use 'general' to indicate that something applies widely without specific details.
Tips.example: The general rules of the game are easy to learn.

Tips.title: Implied Exceptions
Tips.description: 'General' often suggests there may be exceptions to the statement you're making.
Tips.example: General admission tickets are valid for most, but not all, areas.

Tips.title: Not Absolute
Tips.description: 'General' isn't absolute; it leaves room for variations or changes.
Tips.example: The meeting time is 9 AM in general, but it might start later.

Tips.title: Usual Situations
Tips.description: 'General' describes what's normally true, but not necessarily always true.
Tips.example: Dogs are generally friendly, but approach new ones with caution.

Tips.title: Overall Trends
Tips.description: Use 'in general' to talk about the big picture, ignoring small details or outliers.
Tips.example: Teenagers in general prefer texting over talking on the phone.

senses.de: An officer of high rank in the army
senses.ex: He was promoted to the rank of general

Tips.title: High Military Rank
Tips.description: In a military context, 'general' refers to a very high-ranking officer.
Tips.example: The general commanded the troops during the operation.

Tips.title: Authority Implication
Tips.description: 'General' as a noun carries connotations of command and decision-making authority.
Tips.example: As a general, she had a significant impact on military strategy.

senses.de: Applying to all parts and not specific
senses.ex: A general search warrant was issued

Tips.title: Legal Ambiguity
Tips.description: In law, 'general' can make terms less precise, which may be intentional or a point of contention.
Tips.example: The contract's general clause caused a dispute.

Tips.title: Non-specific Approach
Tips.description: Legally, a 'general' designation could mean broad applicability unless specifically limited.
Tips.example: General jurisdiction means the court can hear many types of cases.

Common.wordDefinition:
Common refers to something that is shared or found often within a particular group or area. For example, common interests, common language, common practices.

Common refers to something that is typical within a particular group or area, while general refers to something that is broad and wide-ranging.

Comprehensive.wordDefinition:
Comprehensive means covering or including everything, while general means not specific or particular.

Comprehensive is applicable in situations where a thorough and in-depth understanding or analysis is required. For example, a comprehensive study of a particular subject would cover all aspects of it.

A comprehensive health insurance policy would cover a wide range of medical expenses.

Normal.wordDefinition:
Normal means something that is usual or expected behavior or situation. For example, it is normal for people to go to school or work during weekdays.

To summarize, the word general is used in situations where a broad and widely accepted statement is applicable, whereas the word normal describes a specific incident or behavior that is expected or usual.

Ordinary.wordDefinition:
General refers to something that is common or widespread, while ordinary refers to something that is normal or typical.

For example, a general statement would be "most people like chocolate," while an ordinary statement would be "I ate an ordinary sandwich for lunch."

In terms of usage, general is often used to describe broad concepts or ideas, while ordinary describes everyday or routine experiences.

General refers to the bigger picture, while ordinary relates to the details of day-to-day life.

Overall.wordDefinition:
General refers to things that are basic or common, while overall refers to things that are comprehensive or include everything.

For example, a general description of a city might include information about its population and location, while an overall description might include information about its culture, economy, and geography.

The word general is more appropriate when you want to talk about something that is simple or straightforward, while the word overall is more appropriate when you want to talk about something that is complex or complete.

Regular.wordDefinition:
Regular usually refers to something that occurs or happens at fixed intervals or in a predictable manner.

For example, a regular workout routine means that the same exercises are done at the same time each day or week.

In simpler terms, general means widespread or overall, while regular means consistent or routine. Each word is applicable in different situations depending on the context.

Typical.wordDefinition:
General means something that is widespread or more common, while typical means something that is characteristic or usual in a particular context.

On the other hand, it is typical for students to study hard before exams, meaning that it is expected or usual behavior for students in that situation.

General can describe something that is broad or universal, while typical describes something that is specific to a particular situation or group.

Universal.wordDefinition:
Universal means something that is true of everything, everywhere, and at all times. It applies to things that are fundamental or essential to the nature of things.

For example, a universal law might be gravity or the speed of light.

General is used when something is common or widespread, while universal is used when something is fundamental or essential.

quotes.Text: I feel that confidence in women - especially young girls of color - but women, in general, is so important. It is so important for us to arm ourselves and become powerful at a very young age.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Viola Davis

quotes.Text: There is a difference between happiness and wisdom: he that thinks himself the happiest man is really so; but he that thinks himself the wisest is generally the greatest fool.
quotes.Title: English Philosopher
quotes.Name: Francis Bacon

quotes.Text: The return of my birthday, if I remember it, fills me with thoughts which it seems to be the general care of humanity to escape.

quotes.Text: Increase of material comforts, it may be generally laid down, does not in any way whatsoever conduce to moral growth.

quotes.Text: Take a chance! All life is a chance. The man who goes farthest is generally the one who is willing to do and dare.

quotes.Text: As a general rule, the most successful man in life is the man who has the best information.

quotes.Text: Doctors will have more lives to answer for in the next world than even we generals.
